title: Can you give me some examples of content writing, content marketing and copywriting? - Quora

response.answer_text: Copywriting and content writing are the two most powerful tools of digital marketing. Truth is, every business aims at targeting more audiences and influencing their choices to gain more sales, as well as move the needle in terms of profitability and they do so by employing both these writing techniques. Here’s an explanation, as well as examples of copywriting and content writing: Copywriting is about selling and the art of persuasion. Ad legend David Ogilvy said, “I do not regard advertising as entertainment or an art form, but as a medium of information. When I write an advertisement, I don’t want you to tell me that you find it ‘creative.’ I want you to find it so interesting that you buy the product.” Historically, copywriting mediums included primarily print ads, radio ads, billboards, tv commercials - only. This is about all you saw in the ’60s during the Creative Revolution lead by icons like Mary Wells Lawrence, Bill Bernbach and Jerry Della Femina. Classic ads include Volkswagon’s “Lemon” and Alka Seltzer’s “Plop Plop, Fizz Fizz.” But over the years, with the advent of the Internet, marketing has changed dramatically, and with it, the mediums used to engage customers - and sell products. Content writing is about writing anything, i.e. blogs, articles, interviews, etc. It’s journalistic in style and substance. So it’s less “selly” but still, it seeks to engage the consumer and aims for conversions aka sales. However, content also involves other mediums like infographics, videos, etc. It’s an umbrella term that is wider in scope. Content marketing is a strategic marketing approach that focuses on creating and distributing valuable, relevant and consistent content - which can include both copywriting and content writing - to attract and retain a clearly-defined audience — and, ultimately, drive profitable customer action. Examples of great content include Coke’s “Share A Coke” campaign. It gave everyone the opportunity to personalize their favorite drink. They took the 150 most popular names in Australia and added them to the side of the bottles. And, well… people went crazy for it. Another is Microsoft’s “Stories.” This campaign features individuals who benefited from their products. And what better place to tell theses stories than a blog? But why was it successful? Enjoying a good story is in your DNA. You’re hardwired to connect with it. It releases oxytocin, the feel-good hormone. If you can get your audience to feel emotion with your story, they’ll trust you and buy from you. Here’s two articles that are a deeper dive into all of these topics. When you understand the differences, you can more efficiently implement them into your overall marketing approach. When the content is written with the intent of pursuing the readers to take an action; it is called Copy writing. Examples include asking readers to subscribe/ buy or share a piece of content. When you write a content that is search engine friendly; and/ or you create a campaign on social media to promote it. Then, it becomes Content Marketing. While writing content that is readable and appealing to a defined set of audience is Content Writing.

Content writing and copywriting are essentially the same thing, creating text based content. Copywriting is typically a term used in creating text based content for marketing efforts whereas content writing can be used for any type of text based content creation. Content marketing is when you leverage the content you created for marketing purposes. For example, you would write content to create a blog post describing why your product is better than your competitors.

They’re all pretty similar, so I’ll try to illustrate the differences with an example. Remember the “Got milk?” campaign? It’s an iconic example of ad copywriting. Well, “Got milk?” is copywriting. The quotes by Rachael and Pheobe are examples of content writing. The entire ad, is content marketing.

It doesn’t matter. What you want are sales. And you do it through words. However, one thing to be clear before you write: What’s the purpose of your writing? Are you trying to show your expertise? Are you trying to convert visitors into customers? Are you trying to build a relationship with your audience? Identify the purpose, the call-to-action you want your readers to do. Then start writing…
